channel.title: Microsoft releases open source code?
channel.description:
In an historic move, Microsoft Monday submitted driver source code for inclusion in the Linux kernel under a GPLv2 license. The code consists of four drivers that are part of a technology called Linux Device Driver for Virtualization. The drivers, once added to the Linux kernel, will provide the hooks for any distribution of Linux to run on Windows Server 2008 and its Hyper-V hypervisor technology. Microsoft will provide ongoing maintenance of the code. Linux backers hailed the submission as validation of the Linux development model and the Linux GPLv2 licensing. Microsoft said the move will foster more open source on Windows and help the vendor offer a consistent set of virtualization, management and administrative tools to support mixed virtualized infrastructure. "Obviously we are tickled about it," said Jim Zemlin, executive director of the Linux Foundation. "Hell has frozen over, the seas have parted," he said with a chuckle.
Source: http://www.networkworld.com/news/2009/072009-microsoft-linux-source-code.html?ts0hb&story=mslinux To be honest, Microsoft's just using Linux to compete with VMWare and other virtualization platforms.

item.title: Microsoft releases open source code?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:17, topic:289891”]FLOSS fags amaze me.

“Fucking microsoft, they don’t do enough to ensure interoperability with the open source community”

microsoft makes a patch designed to do exactly that

“Fuck microsoft, we dont want to interoperate with their shit”[/quote]

Not at all, I think it’s great. All I said was I would think most people would run a windows guest on a linux host, not the other way around.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft releases open source code?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:17, topic:289891”]FLOSS fags amaze me.

“Fucking microsoft, they don’t do enough to ensure interoperability with the open source community”

microsoft makes a patch designed to do exactly that

“Fuck microsoft, we dont want to interoperate with their shit”[/quote]
Luckily, I’m not that extreme; and, I don’t believe Moparisthebest is that way either. However, I do believe that Linux should always dominate Windows in my environment.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft releases open source code?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:15, topic:289891”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=383212.msg2877593#msg2877593 date=1248136774]

Who in their right mind would run Linux under a Windows host?

It’s all about virtualization.

What? Linux has Xen, OpenVZ, KVM, VMWare, Virtuozzo, …
[/quote]

But most businesses run Windows server-class operating systems. Sure, they could just run VMWare or some other virtualization software, but chances are they’ll use Microsoft’s. Now they have many more OS’s to virtualize, instead of just windows.[/quote]
Almost all of the businesses I know of use Linux hosts with Windows guests (depending on the job).

Read full topic

Who in their right mind would run Linux under a Windows host?

It’s all about virtualization.
[/quote]
What? Linux has Xen, OpenVZ, KVM, VMWare, Virtuozzo, …[/quote]

But most businesses run Windows server-class operating systems. Sure, they could just run VMWare or some other virtualization software, but chances are they’ll use Microsoft’s. Now they have many more OS’s to virtualize, instead of just windows.

item.title: Microsoft releases open source code?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:13, topic:289891”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=383212.msg2877593#msg2877593 date=1248136774]

Who in their right mind would run Linux under a Windows host?

It’s all about virtualization.

What? Linux has Xen, OpenVZ, KVM, VMWare, Virtuozzo, …
[/quote]
Not forgetting Virtual Box. This advancement probably will mean all Linux distros are supported in Virtual PC.

At least they acknowledge that people want a *NIX on their server.
This might be the most Stable and bug free code ever created by Microsoft.[/quote]
I was mentioning server virtualization software, I would never forget VirtualBox.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft releases open source code?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

That is awesome, maybe hardware manufacturers will start doing this more often, I won’t count on it though.

I have to admit the first thought that popped into my head was this:

T4_:

Who in their right mind would run Linux under a Windows host?

But I guess there are suckers everywhere, right?
